title: Marks & Spencer ditches glitz for its festive campaign by using celebrities already under contract
text:
They have become as much a part of Christmas as mince pies and Brussels sprouts.

But could this be the end of the increasingly lavish, big-budget ads for high street stores battling for festive dominance?

Marks & Spencer has this year decided not to draft in expensive stars for its Christmas campaign and is instead using celebrities who are already under contract.

The company’s advert will focus on food rather than clothing, and it features Amanda Holden, Rochelle Humes, Emma Willis and Paddy McGuinness, who already front regular tasting videos for the high street giant.

The company’s advert will focus on food rather than clothing and it features Amanda Holden and Rochelle Humes, above, who already front regular tasting videos for M&S

They are understood to have already filmed the advert, which is a more restrained affair than last year’s offering with M&S ‘brand ambassador’ Holly Willoughby and model David Gandy, or 2017’s blockbuster campaign with a computer-generated Paddington Bear.

‘The days of spending millions on competing with other shops for the best Christmas campaign very much appears to be a thing of the past,’ a source told The Mail on Sunday last night.

‘There is very little cost attached to this one but it still promises to be very entertaining.’

The savings could help M&S’s bottom line, after its pre-tax profits fell by nearly 10 per cent to £523.2 million in the last financial year.

The company plans to close scores of clothing and homeware stores by 2022.

authors: Katie Hind Showbusiness Editor For The Daily Mail
